text: hello this is chef john from food
wishes.com with no need beer bread
that's right all these years i've been
wasting beer by drinking it and i could
have been making this amazing homemade
rustic beautiful loaf of bread all right
so we're going to start out with a
little bit of dry active yeast in the
bottom of a bowl to which i'm going to
add some flour regular all-purpose flour
and some warm water not scalding hot
that will kill the yeast not just
lukewarm that won't excite the yeast as
much and we want to excite our yeast as
much as possible so let's say you know
about 100 degrees would be ideal all
right so i'm just going to mix that
together i'm going to throw a towel over
it just to keep it covered and we're
going to let that sit in a warm spot for
about 30 minutes and basically what
we're making is called a sponge and 30
minutes later it should look like this
all right kind of gooey kind of bubbly
kind of spongy see that all right to the
sponge i'm going to pour in a 12 ounce
bottle of beer i'm using a belgian style
white al but pretty much anything will
work the beer by the way was room
temperature you could use cold beer just
we'll slow down the process here a
little bit so i'm going to stir that in
once we stir our beer in we are gonna
add our flour which again is just
regular all-purpose flour i guess you
could use bread flour because you know
it's called bread flour we're also gonna
add some salt and believe it or not
that's it bread does not have a lot of
ingredients which is why it's
frustrating when people say i can't make
bread because basically they're saying i
can't combine like three ingredients all
right and there's not a lot of technique
involved here take your wooden spoon and
keep stirring and stirring and stirring
your flour
until you have a thick sticky dough that
pulls away from the sides of the bowl
now if you use my precise measurements
on the blog yours should look pretty
much exactly like this if it looks much
wetter than this add a little more flour
that's okay all right now we're going to
let this rise in a warm spot for two

i'm going to cover this with a damp

i run it out in fact you can even see a

there ideally you want something that's
going to be you know 75 80 degrees that
would be kind of ideal so anyway find a
warm spot let that sit for two hours
until it basically doubles in size all
right and it's going to resemble
something that looks like this so i'm
going to take a spatula and i'm

we're going to generously flour the top
i got flour in my fingers of course and
what you want to do here is form this
into some kind of loaf shape now you can
just leave it like that all right just a
rustic style loaf like we did for our
chapatta bread or you can just roll it

roll it up even it out all right it
feels so amazing if you've never touched

world's greatest sensations there are

feel this amazing under your fingertips
so do not miss this experience all right
once your loaf is formed you're gonna
take a baking sheet a heavy baking sheet
and i like to coat the bottom with

right last step here i'm going to dust
the top of the loaf generously with

what i'm going to do is i'm going to put

helps the rising when it bakes all right
to prepare our oven we're going to
